text: What are the advantages of passing variables through TEMPLATE PARAMS over  session object

elements.text: What are the advantages of passing variables through TEMPLATE PARAMS over  session object

text: uh, with TEMPLATE PARAMS you're writing variables from the server-side into the HTML, while sessionStorage is better used for things like temporary user preferences

elements.text: uh, with TEMPLATE PARAMS you're writing variables from the server-side into the HTML, while sessionStorage is better used for things like temporary user preferences

text: I'm even confused as to why you think both handle the same use cases

elements.text: I'm even confused as to why you think both handle the same use cases

text: I use session object much - I am used since from ASP.

elements.text: I use session object much - I am used since from ASP.

text: okay, hold on

elements.text: okay, hold on

text: I see this problem a lot with beginners to the web, and let me make this clear

elements.text: I see this problem a lot with beginners to the web, and let me make this clear

text: _*Don't ever trust the client*_

elements.text: Don't ever trust the client

text: This includes anything stored in the browser like cookies or session/local storage, as well as the execution of javascript

elements.text: This includes anything stored in the browser like cookies or session/local storage, as well as the execution of javascript

text: They're all subject to user manipulation

elements.text: They're all subject to user manipulation

text: This doesn't mean you shouldn't use any JS, but rather than expecting the browser to do its job right, you should keep the data on your server/database, and verify everything that comes from the client.

elements.text: This doesn't mean you shouldn't use any JS, but rather than expecting the browser to do its job right, you should keep the data on your server/database, and verify everything that comes from the client.

text: You may do some verification in JS in order to prevent reloads, for invalid form fields for example, but you should always verify on the server as well.

elements.text: You may do some verification in JS in order to prevent reloads, for invalid form fields for example, but you should always verify on the server as well.

text: I understand.

elements.text: I understand.

text: But in this case, I will only store the actual page number inside pagination navigation.

elements.text: But in this case, I will only store the actual page number inside pagination navigation.

text: I've changed "browser" to "client" because my point isn't that browsers aren't trustworthy, but that anything stored or run in the browser can be changed or affected by the user.

elements.text: I've changed "browser" to "client" because my point isn't that browsers aren't trustworthy, but that anything stored or run in the browser can be changed or affected by the user.

text: They're not trustworthy from the server-side application's point of view

elements.text: They're not trustworthy from the server-side application's point of view
